Btw Dave, I have cracked vector rotation, relying entirely on scalar and dot products. My solve can also be extended to higher dimensions, as I also standardise with the right-hand rule. I also note that you can find the angle by looking for one co-ordinate on a unit circle, and measure the area beneath it and add the triangle adjacent to it and with its opposite point at the origin, and multiply all by two, to get the answer in radians. But if degrees are your fancy, you gotta multiply instead by 90/π! Or…you could just use a protractor. Et voilà; no calculator needed!

Thanks. after checking several explanations, that finally made me understand.

The dot product is always a scalar, but it is not always positive.  Dot product means multiply corresponding components, and add up the various results.  If some of those components are negative, you very well could get a negative dot product.

Look up "applications of the dot product" to understand what it really means, and put it in to context.  In general, what it means is a measure of how aligned to vectors are, multiplied with the product of their magnitudes.  It takes one vector, projects it onto another, and then multiplies the magnitude of the projection and the first vector.  The go to example to give for the dot product, is work.  Given a force vector and a displacement vector, the dot product of the two, will tell you how much mechanical work the agent of the force transfers to the object as the object moves along the displacement.

A good way to think about the answer to your question, is what is an application of the dot product?  An application of the dot product, is mechanical work.   A dot product of a force and displacement vector yields the amount of work done on the object by the agent of the force, while the object moves a given displacement.  The better aligned the force and displacement are, the more effective the force is at doing work on the object.  A force that is perpendicular to the object's displacement cannot do any work on it, and can only change its direction or offset another force like gravity.   A force that is opposite an object's displacement does negative work on the object, slowing it down.   The closer to 180 degees apart the force and displacement are, the more effective it is at slowing it down.  The dot product measures how aligned two vectors are, and the corresponding product that comes from multiplying their magnitudes, and a factor to quantify their alignment.

Find the dot product between vector A, and the unit vector i that represents the x-direction. Find the magnitude of vector A.  The cosine of the angle between vector A and the x-direction, will equal the aforementioned dot product divided by the magnitude of A.

And that’s not being ‘way over my ass’, if you use your degree wisely then it’s simply not expensive, if you decide to be a fool and get a degree and become a delivery driver then yes, but that’s on the person, not the university. Cosine is a measure of how aligned the vectors are.   Cosine of 1 indicates perfect alignment, as it takes in an angle of zero.  Cosine of -1 indicates the vectors are opposite.  Cosine of zero indicates the vectors are not aligned at all and are perpendicular.
